contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Lord Palmerston 1855.jpg|thumb|200px|Henry Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston, in 1855.]] '''Viscount Palmerston''' was a title in the [[Peerage of Ireland]]. It was created on 12 March 1723 for [[Henry Temple, 1st Viscount Palmerston|Henry Temple]], who subsequently represented [[East Grinstead (UK Parliament constituency)|East Grinstead]], [[Bossiney (UK Parliament constituency)|Bossiney]] and [[Weobley (UK Parliament constituency)|Weobley]] in the [[British House of Commons]]. He was made '''Baron Temple''', of Mount Temple in the County of Sligo, at the same time, also in the Peerage of Ireland. He was succeeded by his son, the second Viscount. He represented seven constituencies in the House of Commons and served as a [[Lord of the Admiralty]] and [[Lord of the Treasury]]. On his death the titles passed to his son, the third Viscount. He was a distinguished politician and served three times as [[Foreign Secretary]] and twice as [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]]. At his death in 1865 he was granted a [[State funerals in the United Kingdom|state funeral]], the fourth non-royal to be given this honour. Lord Palmerston was childless and the barony and viscountcy became extinct on his death. The Temple family descended from Peter Temple, of [[Dorset]] and Marston Boteler. His eldest son John Temple acquired the [[Stowe House|Stowe estate]] in [[Buckinghamshire]] and founded the English branch of the family from whom the [[Viscount Cobham|Viscounts Cobham]], the [[Duke of Buckingham and Chandos|Dukes of Buckingham and Chandos]] and the [[Earl Temple of Stowe|Earls Temple of Stowe]] are descended. Peter Temple's younger son Anthony Temple was the founder of the Irish branch of the family from whom the Viscounts Palmerston descended. His son Sir William Temple (1555–1627) was secretary to [[Philip Sidney|Sir Philip Sidney]] and the [[Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex|Earl of Essex]] and afterwards provost of [[Trinity College, Dublin]]. Sir William's son, [[John Temple (judge)|Sir John Temple]] (1600–1677), was [[Master of the Rolls in Ireland]]. The latter was the father of Sir William Temple, a diplomat, and [[John Temple (politician)|Sir John Temple]] (1632–1704), Speaker of the [[Irish House of Commons]] and father of the first Viscount Palmerston. The third Viscount Palmerston married the Honourable Emily Lamb, sister of Prime Minister [[William Lamb, 2nd Viscount Melbourne|Lord Melbourne]] and widow of Peter Clavering-Cowper, 5th Earl Cowper. Emily's second son from her first marriage, the Honourable [[William Cowper-Temple, 1st Baron Mount Temple|William Cowper]], inherited parts of his stepfather's estates, including [[Broadlands]] near [[Romsey]] in [[Hampshire]], and assumed the additional surname of Temple. In 1880 he was raised to the peerage as [[Baron Mount Temple]], a revival of the junior title held by the Viscounts Palmerston. He was childless and the peerage became extinct on his death in 1888. However, it was revived once again in 1932 in favour of his great-nephew, [[Wilfrid Ashley, 1st Baron Mount Temple|Wilfrid Ashley]]. He had no sons and the title became extinct on his death 1938. His daughter, the Honourable [[Edwina Mountbatten, Countess Mountbatten of Burma|Edwina]], wife of [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Lord Louis Mountbatten]], inherited Broadlands. ==Viscounts Palmerston (1723)== *[[Henry Temple, 1st Viscount Palmerston]] (c. 1673–1757) *[[Henry Temple, 2nd Viscount Palmerston]] (1739–1802) *[[Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston]] (1784–1865) ==See also== *[[Viscount Cobham]] *[[Duke of Buckingham and Chandos]] *[[Earl Temple of Stowe]] ==References== *{{Rayment|date=February 2012}} *[http://67.1911encyclopedia.org/P/PA/PALMERSTON_HENRY_JOHN_TEMPLE.htm Palmerston, Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount], *[[1911 Encyclopædia Britannica]] {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Palmerston}} [[Category:Viscountcies in the Peerage of Ireland]] [[Category:Extinct viscountcies in the Peerage of Ireland]] [[Category:1723 establishments in Ireland]]
